keyTakeAways: China has expanded its export controls on rare-earth metals, now restricting 12 out of 17 known rare-earth elements, including five new ones: holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium.

The restrictions apply to both raw rare-earth metals and specialized equipment used in refining, requiring foreign companies to obtain special approvals with clear justification for the product’s use.
China cites national security and threats of military misuse as justification, claiming certain foreign entities have transferred or processed Chinese rare-earth materials for sensitive applications.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, having imported $22.8 million worth in 2023, with 70% of its rare-earth imports coming from China between 2020 and 2023.

Rare-earth metals are vital for advanced defense technologies (e.g., F-35 jets, submarines, missiles) and civilian applications (e.g., electric vehicles, AI semiconductors, LEDs), making them strategically critical.
The move is seen as a deliberate signaling strategy by China ahead of the Trump–Xi meeting at the APEC summit in South Korea, strengthening Beijing’s leverage in trade negotiations.
While China emphasizes cooperation and supply chain stability, the restrictions underscore the interdependence and vulnerability of global industrial systems.
Exemptions exist for emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, and disaster relief, ensuring essential humanitarian uses are not disrupted.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has announced new export controls on 12 of the 17 known rare-earth metals, including five newly added metals (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium), and restricted access to refining equipment. These measures, effective from December 1, 2025, require foreign companies to obtain special approvals detailing the use of the products, citing national security concerns over military applications. The announcement comes just weeks before a high-stakes meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping during the APEC summit in South Korea, signaling China’s effort to strengthen its negotiating leverage in ongoing trade talks. As the United States is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products—used in critical defense systems like F-35 jets and submarines, and in civilian technologies such as electric vehicles and AI—this move significantly threatens US technological and industrial resilience. Analysts interpret the action as strategic signaling, designed to pressure the US during diplomatic negotiations while highlighting the deep interdependence of the two economies, even as they navigate rising geopolitical tensions.
title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
